notifications.title: Timer is complete!
notifications.oneMinuteStartTime: Next you'll remove your swab from the tube.
notifications.tenMinuteStartTime: Next you'll remove your test strip from the tube.
notifications.connectionError: It looks like your {{device}} is disconnected at the moment. To send your data, please open the app again when you are connected and tap "Try Again."
notifications.resetAppAlertTitle: Do you want to restart the test with a different kit?
notifications.resetAppAlertBody: Saying Yes will reset the app.

emailEntry.emailRequired: Please enter your email to continue.
emailEntry.emailInvalid: That doesn't appear to be a valid email address. Please try again.

Funding.title: Study Funding & Partners
Funding.description:
This app is developed, operated, and owned by [Audere](https://auderenow.org), a digital health non-profit organization in the United States.

The study is sponsored by Audere and Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA), a U.S. Department of Health and Human Services office.

The study is conducted in collaboration with Evidation Health and the University of Washington. Evidation Health is running the study on their Achievement Studies platform.

GeneralQuestions.title: FAQ
GeneralQuestions.whyStudy++Answer:
The goal of this study is to understand if people who are sick should test themselves at home for the flu. As one of the first to try it, you'll play an important role in helping us find ways to manage flu symptoms in the future.

Taking part in this study is completely voluntary. You can stop at any time; however, it greatly helps us if you finish all steps.
GeneralQuestions.howSoon: **How soon should I perform the test after being asked to open the test kit?**
GeneralQuestions.howSoon++Answer: You should download the flu@home app on your {{device}} and complete the test as soon as possible after being asked to open the test kit.
GeneralQuestions.howComplete++Answer: The flu@home app will guide you through all the steps involved in taking the test.
GeneralQuestions.howFindOut: **Will I find out whether I have the flu?**
GeneralQuestions.howFindOut++Answer: Unfortunately, we aren't able to provide that information as part of this study. Neither you nor your healthcare provider will receive the results of the flu test kit done as part of this research. The results are being used for research purposes only. We suggest you contact your healthcare provider for any medical advice.
GeneralQuestions.howLongTest: **How long will the test take me?**
GeneralQuestions.howLongTest++Answer: It should take about 15-20 minutes from start to finish.
GeneralQuestions.swabDirty: **My completed test swab accidentally dropped or came into contact with something else. Should I still complete the test?**
GeneralQuestions.swabDirty++Answer: Yes. Even if you dropped the swab or it touched another surface, please continue with the test steps.
GeneralQuestions.swabTubeLonger: **Is it ok if I left the nasal swab in the Test 1 tube longer than the designated time?**
GeneralQuestions.swabTubeLonger++Answer: Yes. If you left the swab in for a little longer than the timer, please continue with the test steps.
GeneralQuestions.stripLonger: **Is it ok if I left the test strip in the Test 1 tube longer than the designated time?**
GeneralQuestions.stripLonger++Answer: Yes. If you left the test strip in for a little longer than the timer, please continue with the test steps.
GeneralQuestions.whyPersonal: **Why does the app ask me personal questions?**
GeneralQuestions.whyPersonal++Answer: Understanding the conditions surrounding your illness helps us put your potential flu results in context. It also enables us to look for trends among the larger group of participants. Thank you for your willingness to share your information. Some of the questions are optional, and may be skipped if you are not comfortable answering.
GeneralQuestions.willConfidential++Answer:
Your privacy is very important to us and the study team will make every effort to protect the privacy of your data.

You will not be identified personally in any report or publication about this study. We will assign a study code to you and all your information.

For more details, please refer to the flu@home [Privacy Policy](https://fluathome.org/privacy) and the study consent document you signed, available through your Achievement account.
GeneralQuestions.whySendBack: **Why do I need to send my materials back to you?**
GeneralQuestions.whySendBack++Answer: The returned materials will be used to compare your flu@home test strip result with the nasal swab you are shipping back to us. This is a key part of achieving the research goals of the study.
GeneralQuestions.appDelete: **After I finish the tests, may I delete the app?**
GeneralQuestions.appDelete++Answer: Yes. Once you have completed the tests and shipped back your test kit, you may delete the flu@home app from your {{device}}.

ContactSupport.title: Contact Support
ContactSupport.description: Contact us with study questions or problems with the test procedure, kit contents, or the flu@home app. The email address and phone number will be monitored for 6 months after study completion.

ReportComplaint.title: Report a Complaint
ReportComplaint.description:
**What if I have a question, complaint, or any concerns?**

For any questions about the study, your Fitbit, or the flu@home app and test kit, [contact support](CONTACTSUPPORT).

For questions about your rights as a research participant or for questions, concerns, or complaints about the research, please contact Western Institutional Review Board® (WIRB®). WIRB is a group of people who independently review research.

**Address:**
1019 39th Avenue SE Suite 120,
Puyallup, Washington 98374-2115

**Phone number:**
[(800) 562-4789](PHONE) or
[(360) 252-2500](PHONE)

**Email address:**
[help@wirb.com](EMAIL)

surveyTitle.spentTimeCity: Where did you spend the majority of your time this past week?
surveyTitle.whatSymptoms: Have you experienced any of these new or worsening symptoms in the past **24 hours**?
surveyTitle.whenFirstNoticedIllness: When did you first notice your current illness?
surveyTitle.howLongToSickest: How long did it take you to go from feeling not sick at all to feeling the sickest you have felt?
surveyTitle.fluOrCold: Do you think your current illness is the flu or a common cold?
surveyTitle.worseOrDifferentFromTypical: Is your current illness worse or different from a typical cold for you?
surveyTitle.antiviral: Are you taking an antiviral prescribed by a medical professional for the treatment or prevention of flu?
surveyTitle.whenFirstStartedAntiviral: When did you start taking the antiviral medication?
surveyTitle.fluShot: Have you received this season's influenza (flu) vaccine (since July 1, 2019)? This includes both flu mist nasal spray and the flu shot.
surveyTitle.fluShotDate: When did you get the flu vaccine?
surveyTitle.howReceivedFluShot: How did you receive the flu vaccine this season (since July 1, 2019)?
surveyTitle.affectedRegularActivities: How has your current illness affected your ability to do your regular activities (work, school, etc.)?
surveyTitle.householdTobacco: Does anyone in your household currently smoke tobacco?
surveyTitle.travelOutsideState: In the past 7 days, have you traveled outside the state of {{state}}?
surveyTitle.travelOutsideUS: In the past 7 days, have you visited a country other than the US?
surveyTitle.whichCountriesOutsideUS: What country or countries did you visit?
surveyTitle.peopleInHousehold: Including yourself, how many people share your current kitchen or living space?
surveyTitle.childrenAgeGroups: What age groups of children are in your household?
surveyTitle.childrenDaycarePreschool: Do any children in your household attend daycare or preschool?
surveyTitle.someoneDiagnosed: In the past 7 days, has someone you live with been diagnosed with the flu by a medical professional?
surveyTitle.inContact: Do you believe you were exposed to the flu in the past week?
surveyTitle.publicTransportation: In the past week, did you take public transportation?
surveyTitle.aroundSickChildren: In the past week, were you around sick children?
surveyTitle.futureStudies: Are you willing to be contacted for future related studies conducted by the same researchers?
surveyTitle.blueLine: Do you see a blue line in the middle of the test strip?
surveyTitle.pinkLine: Which image below most closely matches your test strip?

surveyDescription.symptomsSeverity: Select the level of discomfort you felt at the worst point
surveyDescription.seeExample: Tap the "?" below to see examples

surveyButton.yesButDontKnowWhich: Yes, but I don't know which medication
surveyButton.yesAboveBlue: Pink line above the blue line
surveyButton.yesBelowBlue: Pink line below the blue line
surveyButton.yesAboveBelowBlue: Pink line above and below the blue line

Welcome.title: Welcome
Welcome.desc:
We know you aren't feeling well right now. Thank you for participating even when you're sick.*

With your help, we want to understand if people (like you) can test themselves at home for the flu. But first, we'll walk you through a few things.
Welcome.desc2: * You must be enrolled in the Achievement --Home Testing of Respiratory Illness-- study to participate. [Tap here if you are not enrolled.](PUSHNAVIGATE:NotEnrolledInStudy)

NotEnrolledInStudy.title: Not enrolled in study
NotEnrolledInStudy.desc:
The flu@home app is intended to be used only by individuals enrolled in the --Home Testing of Respiratory Illness-- study operated through the Achievement Studies platform.

Only participants in the Achievement study who are **invited** to use the app should move forward in the process.

[Get involved with Achievement Studies](https://www.myachievement.com)

HowDoesTestWork.title: How the test works
HowDoesTestWork.desc:
You're about to do two tests, each involving a nasal swab. Don't worry, it shouldn't be too uncomfortable. This app will guide you through each step.

It's important for our study that you complete the tests as **carefully** as possible. In addition, please answer each question as **thoughtfully** as possible.

HowAmIHelping.title: How you are helping researchers
HowAmIHelping.desc: Participating in the flu@home test helps researchers:
HowAmIHelping.desc2:
Determine if app-guided instructions enable people to accurately test themselves at home for the flu
Build models to predict whether someone like you may have the flu
Understand whether an app can read a test strip more accurately than a human can

ResearchStudy.title: Research study
ResearchStudy.desc:
This app supports a research study using the flu@home test kit, an investigational device. This app and test kit do not constitute professional medical or healthcare advice, diagnosis, assessment, or recommendation of treatment and are not intended to, nor should they be used to, replace professional medical advice.

Audere makes no representations or warranties with respect to any treatment, action, suitability or application of medication, or preparation by any person whether in connection with this app and test kit, or not. Under no circumstances will Audere be liable for any direct, indirect, consequential, special, exemplary, or other damages arising therefrom.

ScanInstructions.title: Scan the barcode
ScanInstructions.desc:
Locate the barcode on the outside of the flu@home test kit in the top right corner.

The next screen will ask for access to your camera to scan the barcode.

If your kit doesn't have a barcode, [contact support](CONTACTSUPPORT).

barcode.invalidBarcode: {{barcode}} doesn't look like a flu@home kit barcode. Please try again.
barcode.barcodeRequired: Please enter your kit's barcode to continue.
barcode.dontMatch: Those barcodes don't match. Please try again.

BarcodeScanner.instructions:
Position the barcode in the middle of the outline above.
Try adjusting your distance or angle if the scan is taking a while.

ManualEntry.title: Enter your barcode
ManualEntry.desc: Enter the code found below the barcode symbol on the top right corner of your flu@home test kit.

BarcodeContactSupport.title: Invalid barcode
BarcodeContactSupport.desc:
We're sorry, but the barcode you entered did not match our records.

[Re-enter your barcode](PUSHNAVIGATE:ManualEntry)

If you are still having trouble, [contact support](CONTACTSUPPORT).

BarcodeConnectionToServerError.title: Connect to verify your barcode
BarcodeConnectionToServerError.desc: We could not connect to verify your barcode. Once you are connected, please come back to the app and try again.

EmailConfirmation.title: Verify your email
EmailConfirmation.desc:
Now let's confirm that your kit (barcode {{barcode}}) matches your Achievement account.

Enter the email address you use for Achievement. Here is a hint:

**{{emailHint}}**

EmailError.title: Cannot verify email
EmailError.desc:
Your kit barcode {{barcode}} and email address {{enteredEmail}} did not match an Achievement account on record.

You can re-enter your email, or if you think you've grabbed the wrong kit, you can scan a different kit barcode. Select an option below to try again.

[Re-enter your email](PUSHNAVIGATE:EmailConfirmation)

[Scan a different kit barcode](PUSHNAVIGATE:ScanInstructions)

If you are still having trouble, [contact support](CONTACTSUPPORT).

Unpacking.title: Set up your kit box
Unpacking.desc:
Open the kit box.
Pick up the small bag from the Test 1 side of the box.
Remove the saline vial and tube.
Remove the stopper from the tube.
Stand up the tube in the small hole.

Swab.title: Prepare Test 1 tube
Swab.desc:
Carefully twist open the saline vial.
Squeeze the liquid carefully into the tube so that all the liquid gets into the tube.

OpenSwab.title: Open nasal swab
OpenSwab.desc:
Remove the nasal swab from the paper wrapper by pulling the two ends of the wrapper apart (like you would to open a band-aid).
Be careful to only touch the handle, not the tip.

Mucus.title: Swab nose
Mucus.desc: Gently insert the **entire** soft tip of the swab into one nostril until you feel a bit of resistance.
Mucus.desc2:
Using medium pressure, rub the swab around the inside wall of your nostril four times.
Next, gently insert the **same swab** into the other nostril and rub it around the same way.

SwabInTube.title: Put swab in tube
SwabInTube.desc:
Place the swab into the tube. Make sure the swab tip is touching the bottom of the tube.
Stir it around **four times** in the tube.
Tap "Start timer" below. The swab needs to stay in the tube for one minute.

FirstTimer.title: Did you know?
FirstTimer.desc: If you are sick with flu symptoms, CDC recommends that you stay home for at least 24 hours after your fever is gone except to get medical care or for other necessities.

++tip0.description: You may be able to spread flu to someone else even before you know you are sick. You may be contagious 1 day before symptoms develop and up to 5-7 days after becoming sick.

++tip1.description: Avoid touching your eyes, nose, or mouth. Germs are often spread when a person touches something that is contaminated with germs and then touches his or her eyes, nose, or mouth.

++tip2.description: CDC estimates that many antibiotic prescriptions for acute respiratory infections (including the flu) are unnecessary because most are caused by viruses. Viruses do not respond to antibiotics.

++tip3.description: The most important step in preventing flu is to get a flu vaccination each year. The CDC recommends that you get vaccinated by the end of October each year.

++tip4.description: There are antiviral drugs that can be used to treat the flu in the first couple days of your illness. You can get them if you have a prescription from a health care provider.

++tip5.description: On average, about 8% of the U.S. population gets sick from flu each season.

++tip6.description: Most experts believe that flu viruses spread mainly by tiny droplets made when people with flu cough, sneeze, or talk. These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby.

++tip7.description: Complications of flu can include bacterial pneumonia, ear infections, sinus infections and worsening of chronic medical conditions, such as congestive heart failure, asthma, or diabetes.

++tip8.description: Everyday preventive actions (like staying away from people who are sick, covering coughs and sneezes, and frequent handwashing) help slow the spread of germs that cause the flu.

++tip9.description: Seasonal flu activity often begins as early as October and November and can continue to occur as late as May. Flu activity most commonly peaks in the United States between December and February.

RemoveSwabFromTube.title: Remove swab from tube
RemoveSwabFromTube.desc:
Carefully rub the tip of the swab against the wall of the tube as you pull it out.
Squeeze as much liquid out of the swab as possible.
Throw the swab in the trash. You won't need it again.

OpenTestStrip.title: Open test strip
OpenTestStrip.desc:
Locate the test strip in the white pouch with purple printing.
Open the package by tearing across the top where there is already a small cut.

StripInTube.title: Put test strip in tube
StripInTube.desc:
The arrows on the test strip should be **pointing down** as you lower it into the tube. Make sure the strip is touching the liquid in the bottom.
Leave the test strip in the tube. It needs to be there for at least 10 minutes. We will let you know when to take it out.
In the meantime, please answer some questions so we can better understand how this illness has affected you.

GeneralExposure.title: General exposure
GeneralExposure.desc: In this section, the questions are about recent travel and contact with other people.

ThankYouSurvey.title: Please wait for timer
ThankYouSurvey.desc:
Thank you for completing the survey.

Your test strip is still processing. When the timer ends, the app will direct you to the next step.

TestStripReady.title: Remove test strip
TestStripReady.desc:
Remove the test strip from the tube.
Put the grey stopper securely back on the tube.
Place the test strip on the indent in the middle of the kit box with the arrows pointing down towards you.

TestStripSurvey.title: What do you see?
TestStripSurvey.desc: Look at the test strip with the arrows pointing down towards you to answer the following questions.

RDTInstructions.title: Scan your test strip
RDTInstructions.desc: Next, the app will use your camera to scan your test strip. Please note the instructions below.
RDTInstructions.instructions: Ensure your test strip is in the indent in the middle of the kit box.
RDTInstructions.instructions2: Hold your {{device}} flat and directly above your test strip.
RDTInstructions.desc2: If the test strip doesn't scan within {{rdtTimeoutSeconds}} seconds, you will be asked to take a photo of it using the app.

NonRDTInstructions.title: Take photo of test strip
NonRDTInstructions.desc: Next, we'd like you to take a photo of your test strip using your {{device}}'s camera. The app will access the camera for you.
NonRDTInstructions.instructions: Ensure your test strip is in the indent in the middle of the kit box.
NonRDTInstructions.instructions2: Hold your {{device}} flat and directly above your test strip.
NonRDTInstructions.instructions3: Tap the round button on the screen to take a photo.

RDTReader.centerStrip: Hold your {{device}} flat and directly above the test strip
RDTReader.underExposed: Turn on the flash or move to better lighting
RDTReader.overExposed: Ensure test strip is on the kit box and avoid glare from bright lights

CameraSettings.title: Camera access required
CameraSettings.desc:
We're sorry, but using your {{device}}'s camera is required to continue with the test. If you'd like to continue, please update your settings.

**How to Update:**
CameraSettings.howToIOS:
**Go to Settings / Privacy / Camera / flu@home.**
**Flip the switch to "Yes".**
**Please note: When you return, the camera will be active.**
CameraSettings.howToAndroid:
**Go to Settings / Apps / flu@home / Permissions.**
**Toggle the camera switch to on.**
**Please note: When you return, the camera will be active.**

TestStripCamera.title: Tap the screen to focus the image.
TestStripCamera.description: Tap the button below to take a photo
TestStripCamera.alertTitle: We are unable to scan the test strip
TestStripCamera.alertDesc: The app is having trouble scanning your test strip. Please take a photo of the strip.
TestStripCamera.cameraErrorDesc: We are unable to load the camera and will proceed without taking a photo.
TestStripCamera.error: There was a processing error, please try again

TestStripConfirmation.title: Photo captured
TestStripConfirmation.desc: Your test strip photo was captured successfully.
TestStripConfirmation.diagnosis: Your machine overlord has decided your test result is {{ testResult }}.

PackUpTest.title: Clean up first test
PackUpTest.desc: Now that you've completed the first test, put the Test 1 tube inside the small bag and set it aside.

PrepareUTM.title: Begin second test
PrepareUTM.desc: Please note, this test has different steps from the first one.
PrepareUTM.desc2:
Pick up the Test 2 tube (blue top) from the right side of the box.
Holding it straight so the liquid inside doesn't spill, open the top.
Stand up the tube in the large hole.

OpenSwabUTM.title: Open nasal swab
OpenSwabUTM.desc:
Remove the Test 2 nasal swab from the wrapper.
Be careful to only touch the handle, not the tip.

MucusUTM.title: Swab nose
MucusUTM.desc: Now you'll swab your nose the same way you did in the first test.
MucusUTM.desc2: Gently insert the **entire** soft tip of the swab into one nostril until you feel a bit of resistance.
MucusUTM.desc3:
Using medium pressure, rub the swab around the inside wall of your nostril four times.
Next, gently insert the **same swab** into the other nostril and rub it around the same way.

SwabInTubeUTM.title: Put swab in tube
SwabInTubeUTM.desc:
Place the swab directly into the Test 2 tube.
Screw the blue top back onto the tube tightly.

PackUpUTM.title: Clean up second test
PackUpUTM.desc:
Remove the two bags from the pouch on the kit lid. Put the larger FedEx shipping bag aside.
Put the test strip, Test 2 tube, and the small bag containing the Test 1 tube inside the Lab Guard specimen bag.
Remove as much air as possible from the bag, roll it up, and close it using the zip-top closure.

PackUpBox.title: Prepare kit return package
PackUpBox.desc:
Place the rolled up specimen bag into the pouch on the kit lid and close the kit box.
Place the kit box inside the FedEx shipping bag.
Remove the clear liner at the top of the shipping bag to expose the adhesive, then seal the bag.

Shipping.title: FedEx your kit
Shipping.desc:
Now that your package is ready to go, please send it back as soon as possible. The sample can only be used if it's returned quickly. The return postage is prepaid.

Select an option below to send the kit back:
Shipping.desc2:
[Call FedEx to arrange for a pickup](PUSHNAVIGATE:CallForPickup) from your location
[Drop off your package](PUSHNAVIGATE:WebsiteForDropoff) at a nearby FedEx office or drop box

CallForPickup.title: Call FedEx for pickup
CallForPickup.desc:
Call [(800) GO FEDEX](PHONE:8004633339) to arrange a pickup from your home or office location. If you leave the package on your doorstep for pickup, try not to leave it in direct sunlight or freezing temperatures.

When calling FedEx, the phone system will ask the questions below:
CallForPickup.desc2:
How can I help you? Say "**schedule a pickup**"
To schedule a pickup say "**I am using a label**"
Is the word "stamp" on your label? Say "**no**"
When asked, say the 12-digit tracking number on the bottom of the FedEx shipping label
CallForPickup.desc3:
When asked if they have the correct pickup address say "**no**"
You will be transferred to a FedEx representative who will finish setting up a pickup from your address

WebsiteForDropoff.title: Drop off your package
WebsiteForDropoff.desc:
Use the link below to find a nearby FedEx office or drop box where you can drop off your package.

After opening the link, set "More Filters" to FedEx Office, FedEx Drop Box, and FedEx Ship Center. The package cannot be dropped off at FedEx retail locations such as Office Depot, Walgreens, Safeway, etc.

[Find a FedEx location](DROPOFFPACKAGE:{{state}}/{{city}})

Thanks.title: All done!
Thanks.desc:
Thank you for participating in this research study and helping us find better ways to manage the flu. We hope you feel better soon. If you are concerned about your symptoms, contact your healthcare provider.

[Search Maps for urgent care clinics nearby](https://www.google.com/maps/search/urgent+care+clinics+{{city}}+{{state}})

Learn more about influenza below with information from the Centers for Disease Control (CDC).

fact0.title: **What are the main differences between a cold and the flu?**
fact0.description: Flu and the common cold are both respiratory illnesses, but they are caused by different viruses. Because these two types of illnesses have similar symptoms, it can be difficult to tell the difference between them based on symptoms alone. See [the CDC's page on differences between a cold and the flu](https://www.cdc.gov/flu/symptoms/coldflu.htm) for details.

fact1.title: **What should I do if I am sick?**
fact1.description:
Most people with the flu have mild illness and do not need medical care or antiviral drugs. [According to the CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/flu/treatment/takingcare.htm), if you get sick with flu symptoms, in most cases, you should stay home and avoid contact with other people except to get medical care.

If, however, you have symptoms of flu and are in a high risk group (including young children, people 65 and older, pregnant women and people with certain medical conditions), or are very sick or worried about your illness, contact your healthcare provider (doctor, physician assistant, etc.).

fact2.title: **Do I need to go to the emergency room if I am sick?**
fact2.description: The emergency room should be used for people who are very sick. See [the CDC's page on emergency warning signs for flu](https://www.cdc.gov/flu/treatment/takingcare.htm#anchor_1553702039) for which you should go to the emergency room.

fact3.title: **Are there medications to treat the flu?**
fact3.description: There are medications your healthcare provider may prescribe for treating the flu called "antivirals." See [the CDC's page on antiviral drugs for the flu](https://www.cdc.gov/flu/treatment/whatyoushould.htm) for more information.

fact4.title: **How long should I stay home if I'm sick?**
fact4.description: The CDC recommends that you [stay home for at least 24 hours after your fever is gone](https://www.cdc.gov/flu/treatment/takingcare.htm) except to get medical care or for other necessities. Your fever should be gone without the need to use a fever-reducing medicine, such as Tylenol®. Until then, you should stay home from work, school, travel, shopping, social events, and public gatherings.

fact5.title: **Do people with the flu always have a fever?**
fact5.description: A fever is a sign that your body is fighting an infection. Fevers for flu-related illnesses are typically 100˚F (38˚C) or higher. However, not everyone who has the flu will have a fever. See [healthline's description of flu symptoms](https://www.healthline.com/health/cold-flu/early-flu-symptoms) to learn more.

PendingData.title: Connect to upload data
PendingData.desc:
We could not connect to upload your data. Once you are connected, please come back to the app and try again.

It may take a minute to sync your data.

links.notEnrolledInStudy: Tap here if you are not enrolled
links.CDC: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: Antiviral drugs may be an option
links.skipTestStripPhoto: Unable to take a picture? Skip this step
